newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: SBC details financial implications of move.
newsitem.headline: SBC details financial implications of move.

text.p: Swiss Bank Corp. (SBC) said a radical change in its method of provisioning, new structures in its domestic division and a revaluation of its Swiss real estate portfolio would lead to a one-time technical loss of around 1.9 billion Swiss francs in 1996.
SBC said in a statement that this one-time loss compares with an expected group net profit of around 1.4 billion francs for 1996.
"All these initiatives will already have a further positive impact in 1997," SBC said.
SBC also said the restructuring of its domestic division should lead to a substantial improvement in earnings of around 400 million francs in the next three years.
"The future freeing up of capital in the domestic division and the low capital intensity of the further expansion projects at group level will permit a one-time reduction in share capital," SBC said.

To mark the bank's 125th anniversary, the board of directors would propose to the annual shareholders' meeting on May 13, 1997 that instead of a dividend, a capital repayment of 10 francs in nominal capital per share be made, without any tax deduction.
The nominal value of SBC's share will thus fall to 40 francs from 50 francs.
It noted that regulatory authorities, the federal banking commission and rating agencies had been notified of these plans.
SBC said that by a systematic implementation of its measures, it intends to achieve a return of equity (ROE) of around 15 percent after tax on a capital base of around 16 billion francs.
